content: ETF Investments Asked by AnonymousAsked on 21 Mar 2019Investing into Irish-domiciled S&P 500 ETF?I am already vested in US-domiciled etfs (VTI, VGK, VPL, VWO) via Autowealth. I am now also looking into manually invest into Irish-domiciled etf to reduce the withholding tax from 30% to 15%. I am looking at the S&P 500 index, and some recommended the CSPX fund by iShares which is also an accumulating fund. Any other irish-domiciled etfs that tracked the S&P 500 worth considering?  In addition, any things to keep in mind when buying Irish-domiciled etf? many thanks :)4 answersAnswerBump1
Answers (4)Sort By Most UpvoteMost UpvoteMost Recent
Nicholes Wong, Diploma in Business Management at Nanyang PolytechnicLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 22 Mar 2019VUSD is another one you can consider but its not accumulating etf.0 comments1

Gabriel Tham, Kenichi Tag Team Member at Tag TeamLevel 8. WizardAnswered on 21 Mar 2019I believe ishares or vanguard will offer one of the lowest expense ratios already. These 2 giants are the biggest and competing directly with each other for etf investors.Personally, I prefer all-world etf. US still a big portion of the world etf but in the case that US falls off, at least the etf would balance into other countries.0 comments1
Kevin HoLevel 2. RookieUpdated on 01 Jun 2019You can check out VUSD. There's a guide on this here:  https://financialhorse.com/withholding-tax/0 comments0

Kenneth Lou, Co-founder at SeedlyLevel 8. WizardUpdated on 21 May 2019Hi there! I wrote about this extensively here:But to touch on your last point... On some things to note.What i understand is that the Ireland domiciled ETFs closely replicate the Similar composition of the US ETF, so in that sense it’s the same thing but with:lower transaction volume (bid ask spreads)sightly higher expense ratiosBut your witholding tax on your dividends are at 15% instead of the normal 30% tax if you were to directly buy a US domiciled ETF.Personally, i’ve not done this but based on extensive research this is what I’ve found!0 comments0
